title: EIB Papers Volume 06. n°1/2001
snippet: European economic growth: The impact of new technologies Preface by Philippe Maystadt, President Wonders will never cease: Prospects for a new economy in Europe (Christopher Hurst and Kristian Uppenberg) Productivity growth prospects and the new economy in historical perspective ( Paul David) Measuring economic growth and the new economy (Patrick Vanhoudt and Luca Onorante) ICT clusters in development: Theory and evidence (Danny Quah) Nothing ventured, nothing gained (Hermann Hauser) Regional development and the new economy (Andrew Gillespie, Ranald Richardson and James Cornford) Computers and employment: The truth about e-skills (Luc Soete and Bas ter Weel) The diffusion of information technology in Europe (Harald Gruber) To read the individual articles, please follow the respective links. The full version is accessible below.

T h i sphenomenon involves what we call innovational complementarities IC, that is, theproductivity of RD in a downstream sector increases as a consequence of innovationin the GPT technology. These complementarities magnify the effects of innovation inthe GPT, and help propagate them throughout the economy. strongcomplementarities with existing or potential new technologies.    James Watts separate condenser steam engine design springs to mind readily as an example ofan innovation that meets these criteria, and, indeed, it is widely accepted as the GPT that isemblematic of the first industrial revolution. title: Don't fear AI
snippet: A new production revolution, enabled in part by artificial intelligence (AI), is now emerging, bringing a new wave of technologies, but there are widespread fears that these changes also will bring a big rise in unemployment as machines replace human beings in big numbers. This is the second essay in the Big Ideas series created by the European Investment Bank.

people.snippet:
One recent study found that over one-third of US college graduates are overeducated in terms of the jobs they
have, with similar numbers for EU nations. See Research working paper by Brian Clark and Arnaud Maurel from
Duke University and Clément Joubert from University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill titled The Career Prospects
of Overeducated Americans, which uses data from the National Longitudinal “Survey of Youth” 1979 and “Current
Population Survey” to look at overeducation’s effects on employment and wages over time. To analyse these effects,
the researchers tracked almost 5,000 college graduates for 12 years after they entered the workforce. Their study shows
that over one-third of college graduates are working in what the researchers call “overeducated employment”;
https://www.bls.gov/opub/mlr/2013/article/clayton.htm; https://www.bls.gov/osmr/abstract/ec/ec060110.htm

Carl Benedikt Frey and Michael A. Osbourne, The Future of Employment: How Susceptible Are Jobs to Computerisation?,
Oxford Martin School, University of Oxford, Oxford, September 17, 2013,
http://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/downloads/academic/The_Future_of_Employment.pdf

Otto Toivanen (otto.toivanen@helsinki.fi) is Director at the Helsinki
Center of Economic Research (HECER ), University of Helsinki. Jarle
Møen, Associate Professor at the Norwegian School of Economics and
Business Administration (Bergen, Norway), was instrumental in giving
background information on Norway and Jyrki Ali-Yrkkö, Head of Unit at
the Research Institute of the Finnish Economy in helping with numbers
regarding Finnish firms’ R&D investments. The author is responsible for
all opinions and remaining errors.

Otto TOIVANEN,
of the University of Helsinki, Finland

Philippe MARTIN,
of the University of Paris-1,
Panthéon-Sorbonne, France

of Lund University, Sweden

of the University of Cambridge, UK

highlights.text: relevance if technologies are what Bresnahan and Trajtenberg 1995 labelgeneralpurpose technologies  GPT for short. To cite them pp. 84: Most GPTs play the roleof enabling technologies, opening up new opportunities rather than offering complete, finalsolutions. An important characteristic of GPTs is that they foster complementary innovations.They, in turn, may lead to improvements in the GPT, which in turn benefits other unrelatedcomplementary innovations. Often cited examples of GPTs are the

generalpurpose technologies see Klette and Møen 1999. Two consequences of theconcerns mentioned above and the GPT orientation of Norways RD policy are worth mentioning.For one thing, RD funding of the programme was substantial, reaching some 40 percent of thetotal funding for research carried out by universities and government laboratories. To initiate thekind of positive feedback loop envisioned by the GPT theory, largescale initial investments mightbe necessary. Second, there was a heavy concentration on

Erik Brynjolfsson (erikb@mit.edu) is Professor of Economics and Digital
Business at the Sloan School of Management and the Center for Digital
Business of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) and senior
research associate at the National Bureau of Economic Research (NBER).
The author would like to thank Ben Bernanke, Dale Jorgenson, Heekyung
Kim, Gary Loveman, Andrew McAfee, Adam Saunders, Michael Schrage,
Dan Sichel, Scott Stern, Hubert Strauss and Lynn Wu for valuable comments
and conversations on this topic and the MIT Center for Digital Business for
generous financial support.
